results.title: With ‘In the Heights,’ Anthony Ramos Finds Stardom on His Own Terms
results.abstract: Teachers urged him to cultivate a more ethnically ambiguous image. He refused, and now he’s having a breakout moment.

multimedia.caption: Anthony Ramos in Bushwick. Spike Lee said of the actor: “He was not handed this artistic life. He had to put the work in.”

results.title: For ‘F9,’ Making Stunts That Stick
results.abstract: The concept of electromagnets factors heavily into the new film, creating the impression of cars stuck together and leaving stacks of wreckage in a way only the “Fast and the Furious” films know how.

results.title: The Surprising Evolution of Cruella De Vil
results.abstract: From a calm socialite, she morphed into an unhinged puppy kidnapper and then a vindictive glamourpuss. Why don’t we hate her?

multimedia.caption: Cruella de Vil in “One Hundred and One Dalmatians.” The 1961 animated film gave the character a more crazed temperament than in the original children’s novel.

results.title: Jerome Hellman, Producer of ‘Midnight Cowboy,’ Dies at 92
results.abstract: His movie-producing career consisted of just seven films, but they earned him six Academy Awards, three for “Midnight Cowboy” and three for “Coming Home.”

multimedia.caption: Jon Voight, left, and Dustin Hoffman in a scene from the 1969 film “Midnight Cowboy,” the only X-rated film ever to win the best picture Oscar.

results.title: The Toasts Are Mimed, but the Kennedy Center Honors Return
results.abstract: The pandemic made the ceremony, honoring Debbie Allen, Joan Baez, Garth Brooks, Midori and Dick Van Dyke and airing on TV Sunday, like no other.

results.title: Bo Burnham’s ‘Inside’: A Comedy Special and an Inspired Experiment

results.title: Lines Never Felt So Good: Crowds Herald New York’s Reopening
results.abstract: Museums broke attendance records, movie theaters sold out and jazz fans packed clubs on a Memorial Day weekend that felt far removed from the prior year’s pandemic traumas.

multimedia.caption: With vaccinations up and coronavirus restrictions easing, New Yorkers are flocking back to cultural venues: the Metropolitan Museum of Art drew more than 10,000 visitors a day this weekend, the most since the start of the pandemic.
multimedia.copyright: Lila Barth for The New York Times

results.title: Natalie Morales Makes Her Directing Debut. Twice.
results.abstract: With “Plan B” and “Language Lessons,” the actress is finally getting to start a career behind the camera, a goal one talent agency couldn’t understand.

results.title: Film or Real Life?
results.abstract: Sometimes a place is more than just a place; it can be a scene. Even the blankest backdrops, like a parking lot or a sun-baked freeway, can shimmer with cinematic potential. Four photographers showed us the movie moments that they found all over.
results.byline: By Jolie Ruben, Amanda Webster and Raillan Brooks

results.title: ‘Apocalypse ’45’ Review: Graphic Images of Wartime
results.abstract: Candid testimonies from World War II veterans accompany vivid archival footage in this immersive documentary that showcases the myths we tell ourselves about war.

results.title: ‘Her Man’: A Relic of a Bygone Hollywood, Now Restored
results.abstract: Now streaming, this mildly racy romance, from 1930, arrived before the censorious Production Code. What really sets the film apart is its incredible tracking shots.

results.title: Mike Faist Isn’t Sure About This Whole Acting Thing
results.abstract: “I can’t tell if I hate acting or if I love it too much,” he said ahead of the debut of the Amazon series “Panic.” Coming soon, a major role in Steven Spielberg’s “West Side Story.” For now, he’s going to Ohio.

multimedia.caption: Mike Faist’s acting career has been ascendent, and atypical, since he dropped out of acting school at 18.
